author: Lam Ka-song
title: Hong Kong developers, property agents turn to virtual reality
content: Hong Kong's tightened social distancing measures have cast a shadow on the property market. But as new project launches are delayed because of the fifth wave of the coronavirus outbreak, <mark id='1647883026008'>real estate agencies and developers are shifting their focus online to boost sales.</mark>

Starting from Thursday, <mark id='1647883089165'>the city will impose an unprecedented ban on private gatherings of more than two households</mark>, temporarily close houses of worship and hair salons, and reduce the cap on public gatherings to just two people.

<mark id='1647884791063'>A total of 2,015 nano flats, with a saleable floor area of 215 square feet or less, are expected to be ready this year</mark>, compared with 960 units in 2021, according to JLL. These include 418 units at The Royale in Tuen Mun, 380 units in Manor Hill in Tseung Kwan O and 288 units at The Met. Azure in Tsing Yi.

The era of nano flats in Hong Kong is likely to end soon. <mark id='1647873089165'>The availability of such flats is set to peak this year</mark>, after the government put a cap on the minimum size of homes late last year, say market observers.

Centaline Property Agency expects fewer than 500 first-hand transactions this month, the lowest in 24 months, as these measures keep prospective buyers away. The agency expects second-hand property viewings to sink by half compared with levels seen before the Lunar New Year, which could push lived-in homes prices down 3 to 5 per cent compared with the end of last year.
